title: What is Article 50? Time to get to grips with leaving the European Union with our Brexit guide
text:

Time to get to grips with leaving the European Union with our Brexit guide With the date for the UK officially leaving the EU fast approaching, this is what has been agreed as of March 2018 Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! We are set to leave the EU on March 29, 2019 and the 12-month countdown has begun. 
It’s a thought that scares and excites people in equal measure but even now not everyone is clear as to what is happening and why and what has been agreed so far. 
So let us help you get clued up on the Brexit story so far. 
OK, just remind us how we got here An EU flag flying in front of the Houses of Parliament (Image: PA) 
On June 23, 2016, the UK voted by 17.4 million to 16.1 million to leave the European Union. It was a huge surprise for which Sunderland took a disproportionate amount of blame from those who wanted to remain in Europe. Even the New York Times turned up there to ask the people of Wearside why they voted to leave the EU. 
And what’s happened in the intervening couple of years? 
We’ve had a change in Prime Minister , a general election which both main parties seemed to argue they’d won not lost, and the Government was taken to court to ensure that Parliament should vote on triggering Article 50. 
Article 50 - it’s been a while since I’ve heard the term so, enlighten us as to what it is again 
It’s a section contained within the Lisbon Treaty. This Treaty was signed in 2007 by the leaders of all countries which are EU members and its idea was to make the EU more democratic, transparent and efficient. It came into force in 2009. Read More What is Article 50? 
What does Article 50 do? 
It gives members the right to leave the EU. Before that, they had no legal way to leave once they’d signed up. “Triggering” it means formally telling the other EU members of our intention to pull out. 
And we of course did this ... when? Prime Minister Theresa May (Image: PA) 
In March 2017, nine months after the UK voted for Brexit. Prime Minister Theresa May signed a letter triggering the process, which was handed over to the European Council’s president Donald Tusk who didn’t look very happy about it. 
This was followed by a statement from Mrs May to the House of Commons, where she said now was “the moment for the country to come together”, words that proved wildly optimistic. Read More Brexit will mean less money and more work for North East charities as they fight against hatred 
What happened next? 
Lots of talking until on March 19 a transition agreement, which is conditional on both sides agreeing a final withdrawal treaty, was signed. 
The transitional period will last from Brexit day on March 29, 2019 to December 31, 2020. 
What does this mean? 
It mean EU citizens arriving in the UK between these two dates will enjoy the same rights and guarantees as those who arrive before Brexit. The same will apply to UK expats on the continent. 
The UK’s share of fishing catch will be guaranteed during transition but UK will effectively remain part of the Common Fisheries Policy, yet without a direct say in its rules, until the end of 2020. Northern Ireland will effectively stay in parts of the single market and the customs union in the absence of other solutions to avoid a hard border with the Republic of Ireland. Read More 'Stop taking us for idiots': Theresa May facing Brexit backlash from North East employers 
What about trade deals outside the EU? 
The UK will be able to negotiate, sign and ratify its own trade deals during the transition period. The UK will still be party to existing EU trade deals with other countries Like us on Facebook
